title: Arsenal in some of the best form in their history, surprise stats show
text:
Arsene Wenger isn’t doing as bad a job as it seems (Picture: Getty) Everyone’s pretty much agreed that Arsenal are in decline; that they’re going backwards under Arsene Wenger – or at best, staying still.
Why Arsene Wenger is RIGHT to play David Ospina over Petr Cech But stats looking at the Gunners’ win percentage in recent seasons show they’re actually in some of the best form in their history – so what on earth has gone wrong?
It’s not a popular opinion to take, but some less pessimistic sections of the Arsenal support (think there are still one or two knocking about) will tell you that the club is actually in better shape than ever – the only problem is that so is everyone else.
Arsenal are currently winning more than the Invincibles (Picture: Getty) Wenger had a far more successful first half of his reign than second, but until 2003 he only had Manchester United to contend with in the Premier League. Everything changed when Roman Abramovich bought Chelsea, and since then there has also been significant cash pumped into Manchester City, while Tottenham are also hugely improved.
According to findings by Opta’s Orbinho , Arsenal have actually managed to achieve win percentages up there with the best sides in their history three times in the last four seasons.
Arsenal’s best ever record was 66% all the way back in 1930/31, followed closely by 65% in their double-winning year of 2001/02.
Best-ever Arsenal win % (all comps) 1930/31 66 2001/02 65 2016/17 (ongoing) 64 1970/71 64 2014/15 63 2013/14 63 2003/04 63 1990/91 62 2007/08 62 Share

However, this season’s side is currently on 64% – just one short of that team containing the likes of Thierry Henry and Robert Pires at their peak that is regarded as one of the finest sides in Premier League history.
Not only that, it’s level with the 1970/71 double winners, and actually ahead of the 63% win percentage achieved by the 2003/04 Invincibles.

Of course, the season is not over yet so the number could go down, but the 2013/14 and 2014/15 sides also achieved a very respectable 63% record, while the class of 2007/08 that narrowly missed out on the title ended with 62%.
In short, the standards have been raised and Arsenal can count themselves pretty unlucky to have just come up short so many times. Yes, their big game record could be far better, but there are more big games now than ever before. As well as that, off the pitch there is increased competition in the transfer market, and the Gunners aren’t quite in a position to outspend the likes of Chelsea and City on the players they perhaps would’ve landed in the past.
In different eras, they’d have won a great deal more. Time for Arsenal fans to take the work Wenger’s done with a little perspective?
